articles.headline: A Collision of Creativity and Cash
articles.snippet: While Disney focuses on lucrative franchises, Pixar maintains it is devoted to the story. In “Cars 2,” Disney won.
articles.abstract: While Disney focuses on lucrative franchises, Pixar maintains it is devoted to the story. In “Cars 2,” Disney won.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Walt Disney Company bought Pixar Animation Studios for $7.4 billion in 2006, there was understandable concern that the media conglomerate that drove the famed Disney animation unit into the ground with duds like “Home on the Range” and “Chicken Little” would extinguish the creative flame that had nurtured the quirky and much-loved “Toy Story” and “Finding Nemo.”

articles.headline: A New Type of Student Loan, but Still a Risk
articles.snippet: Fixed-rate student loans from banks are a welcome innovation, but they should serve as a reminder of the hazards of this kind of debt.
articles.abstract: Fixed-rate student loans from banks are a welcome innovation, but they should serve as a reminder of the hazards of this kind of debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are two possible reactions to the news in recent weeks that U.S. Bank and Wells Fargo are now offering fixed-rate student loans in addition to the variable rate kind that had been standard.

articles.headline: An Accordion Epicenter Shrinks and Thrives
articles.snippet: An Italian town that has been the home of high-end accordion makers for decades has survived by focusing on quality.
articles.abstract: An Italian town that has been the home of high-end accordion makers for decades has survived by focusing on quality.
articles.lead_paragraph: CASTELFIDARDO, Italy — Jet-lagged but determined, Salomon Salcedo thought nothing of trekking to this small hilltop town in the Marches region on a muggy June afternoon to satisfy a lifelong desire: buy a made-in-Castelfidardo accordion.

articles.headline: What’s Inside the Bun?
articles.snippet: Manufacturers of processed meats like frankfurters are pushing for more accurate labeling rules when it comes to cancer-causing nitrite and nitrate.
articles.abstract: Manufacturers of processed meats like frankfurters are pushing for more accurate labeling rules when it comes to cancer-causing nitrite and nitrate.
articles.lead_paragraph: If there is no such thing as a healthy hot dog, how do you limit the damage at this weekend’s weenie roast?

articles.headline: U.S. Expands Its Drone War Into Somalia
articles.snippet: New evidence indicates that Al Qaeda’s franchise in Yemen and the Islamist militancy in Somalia are possibly plotting attacks against the United States.
articles.abstract: New evidence indicates that Al Qaeda’s franchise in Yemen and the Islamist militancy in Somalia are possibly plotting attacks against the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The clandestine American military campaign to combat Al Qaeda’s franchise in Yemen is expanding to fight the Islamist militancy in Somalia, as new evidence indicates that insurgents in the two countries are forging closer ties and possibly plotting attacks against the United States, American officials say.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: World Bank Is Opening Its Treasure Chest of Data
articles.snippet: Robert B. Zoellick, the World Bank president, argues that its most valuable currency isn’t money — it’s information.
articles.abstract: Robert B. Zoellick, the World Bank president, argues that its most valuable currency isn’t money — it’s information.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

articles.headline: The Swindler and the Home Loans
articles.snippet: After a theft involving home loans, should lenders bear any blame? That’s at issue in a case now in a New York State court.
articles.abstract: After a theft involving home loans, should lenders bear any blame? That’s at issue in a case now in a New York State court.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLDING banks accountable for all those disastrous mortgages has been remarkably difficult. But last week, a big bank agreed to pay a price: Bank of America announced that it would part with $8.5 billion to settle claims that its Countrywide Financial unit had packaged garbage loans into investments that were said to be safe.

articles.headline: We Knew They Got Raises. But This?
articles.snippet: Updated figures show that median pay surged 23 percent last year for top executives at 200 big companies.
articles.abstract: Updated figures show that median pay surged 23 percent last year for top executives at 200 big companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT turns out that the good times are even better than we thought for American chief executives.

articles.headline: Budget Needs Let Fireworks Fly Lawfully
articles.snippet: As elected officials try to cash in on fireworks sales in cities and counties where they have long been banned, consumers will find it easier to buy fireworks.
articles.abstract: As elected officials try to cash in on fireworks sales in cities and counties where they have long been banned, consumers will find it easier to buy fireworks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Fourth of July promises to be more explosive than ever this year in cities and counties where fireworks had been banned for decades.

articles.headline: Taking Lead, Iraqis Hope U.S. Special Operations Commandos Stay
articles.snippet: Members of Iraq’s well-trained special operations force say that American troops must stay longer to continue training and advising.
articles.abstract: Members of Iraq’s well-trained special operations force say that American troops must stay longer to continue training and advising.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — In darkness and dressed in black, the American and Iraqi Special Operations commandos navigated the dense urban neighborhood here in the capital and approached a house they believed to be a hide-out for two brothers suspected of carrying out assassinations and car-bomb attacks. As the Iraqis bashed in the door, the sound of glass shattering and screams pierced the nighttime stillness.

articles.headline: Some With Histories of Mental Illness Petition to Get Their Gun Rights Back
articles.snippet: Across the country, states are increasingly allowing people who lost their firearm rights because of mental health issues to appeal to have them restored.
articles.abstract: Across the country, states are increasingly allowing people who lost their firearm rights because of mental health issues to appeal to have them restored.
articles.lead_paragraph: PULASKI, Va. — In May 2009, Sam French hit bottom, once again. A relative found him face down in his carport “talking gibberish,” according to court records. He later told medical personnel that he had been conversing with a bear in his backyard and hearing voices. His family figured he had gone off his medication for bipolar disorder, and a judge ordered him involuntarily committed — the fourth time in five years he had been hospitalized by court order.

articles.headline: Big Banks Easing Terms on Loans Deemed as Risks
articles.snippet: Two of the nation’s biggest lenders are quietly modifying loans for tens of thousands of borrowers who have not asked for help but whom the banks deem to be at special risk.
articles.abstract: Two of the nation’s biggest lenders are quietly modifying loans for tens of thousands of borrowers who have not asked for help but whom the banks deem to be at special risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: As millions of Americans struggle in foreclosure with little hope of relief, big banks are going to borrowers who are not even in default and cutting their debt or easing the mortgage terms, sometimes with no questions asked.

articles.headline: Thais Back Ousted Prime Minister’s Party in Landslide
articles.snippet: The overwhelming victory for the Pheu Thai party was a vindication for Thaksin Shinawatra, a populist champion of Thailand’s rural poor who was ousted in a 2006 coup.
articles.abstract: The overwhelming victory for the Pheu Thai party was a vindication for Thaksin Shinawatra, a populist champion of Thailand’s rural poor who was ousted in a 2006 coup.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The party of the fugitive former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra won an overwhelming victory in a parliamentary election on Sunday that could turn Thai politics on its head and roll back the results of a coup that ousted Mr. Thaksin almost five years ago.
articles.byline: By Seth Mydans and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: To Keep Parking Lots Full, Retailers Offer Gas Deals
articles.snippet: Gas prices are having a direct effect on shoppers’ behavior, so some stores are offering gas discounts.
articles.abstract: Gas prices are having a direct effect on shoppers’ behavior, so some stores are offering gas discounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: With gas prices locked at well above $3 a gallon, some retailers and manufacturers are trying to get more shoppers back on the road by picking up some costs at the pump.

articles.headline: Carmakers and White House Haggling Over Mileage Rules
articles.snippet: The administration wants new American cars and trucks to average as much as 56.2 miles per gallon by 2025, roughly double the current level.
articles.abstract: The administration wants new American cars and trucks to average as much as 56.2 miles per gallon by 2025, roughly double the current level.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration and the auto industry are locked in negotiations over new vehicle mileage and emissions standards that will have a profound effect on the cars Americans drive and the health of the auto industry over the next decade and beyond.

articles.headline: Homework Help Site Has a Social Networking Twist
articles.snippet: Piazza, a Web site for homework help, builds on classroom community by having peers and educators respond to questions.
articles.abstract: Piazza, a Web site for homework help, builds on classroom community by having peers and educators respond to questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Pooja Nath was an undergraduate at the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, an elite engineering school in India, she felt isolated. She was one of the few women on campus. While her male classmates collaborated on problem sets, Ms. Nath toiled in the computer lab alone.

articles.headline: Networks Want Slices of a New Pie
articles.snippet: The fees that cable and satellite operators pay local stations have produced big revenues, and some disputes. Now, networks want a share of these fees.
articles.abstract: The fees that cable and satellite operators pay local stations have produced big revenues, and some disputes. Now, networks want a share of these fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, KSFX, a Fox television station in the Ozarks, told its viewers that the Fox part was going away in the fall. The station said it would still show all of its local newscasts, but the station’s fans on Facebook had other concerns. What about “American Idol”? they asked. What about “Bones”?

articles.headline: Tools of Entry, No Need for a Key Chain
articles.snippet: Technology that allows doors to be unlocked remotely is moving to the smartphone, causing some analysts to say the key will soon become obsolete.
articles.abstract: Technology that allows doors to be unlocked remotely is moving to the smartphone, causing some analysts to say the key will soon become obsolete.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Front pockets and purses are slowly being emptied of one of civilization’s most basic and enduring tools: the key. It’s being swallowed by the cellphone.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Verne G. Kopytoff

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Seeking Gains in Greek Crisis
articles.snippet: The twists and turns of the Greek crisis and the whipsaw market activity have made it difficult for some hedge funds to maneuver.
articles.abstract: The twists and turns of the Greek crisis and the whipsaw market activity have made it difficult for some hedge funds to maneuver.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a tough year for the London-based hedge fund Algebris Investments.

articles.headline: French See Case Against Strauss-Kahn as American Folly
articles.snippet: A dormant anti-Americanism has been reawakened, fueled by a sense that the media-driven culture of the United States has undermined justice and fair play in the case of Dominique Strauss-Kahn.
articles.abstract: A dormant anti-Americanism has been reawakened, fueled by a sense that the media-driven culture of the United States has undermined justice and fair play in the case of Dominique Strauss-Kahn.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The stunning reversals in the criminal case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn, a putative French presidential candidate, have reawakened a dormant anti-Americanism here, fueled by a sense that the raw, media-driven culture of the United States has undermined justice and fair play.

articles.headline: In Joplin, Mo., a Declaration of Endurance
articles.snippet: Monday’s celebration in the partially destroyed city of Joplin is designed to brighten the faces of all looking skyward.
articles.abstract: Monday’s celebration in the partially destroyed city of Joplin is designed to brighten the faces of all looking skyward.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOPLIN, Mo. — For the last few nights, brief shimmers of fireworks have sparkled in the dark skies over Joplin, heralding the approach of another national birthday. But the monstrous tornado that mowed through here six weeks ago forced the city to change its Fourth of July plans.

articles.headline: Congress’s Man of the Vines, Including His Own
articles.snippet: Representative Mike Thompson is not only the wine industry’s foremost champion in Washington. He is also a vineyard owner.
articles.abstract: Representative Mike Thompson is not only the wine industry’s foremost champion in Washington. He is also a vineyard owner.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAPA, Calif. — The local wine industry’s biggest names — and boldest blends — were gathered here one afternoon in February for the annual auction that is the Napa equivalent of the Academy Awards. There, pouring wine along with well-known figures like Tim Mondavi, was another industry celebrity: Representative Mike Thompson, Democrat of California.
